metadata.title: Facile synthesis of ultra-stable Co-N-C catalysts using cobalt porphyrin and peptides as precursors for selective oxidation of ethylbenzene

Scheme 1 The preparation of Co-N-C catalysts. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 (a) The colors of the solution; (b) FT-IR spectra of phenylalanine and the solid sample; (c,d) TEM images of Co-N-C-Phen, inset chart (c) the particle-size distribution histogram; (e) SEM image and SEM-EDX elemental mapping images of Co-N-C-Phen. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TEM images of (a) NI-Co-N-C-Phen, (b) Co-N- C-N A, (c) Co-N-C-PR, (d) Co-N-C-Cap, (e) Co-N-C-Buty, and (f) Co-N- C-H is. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of Co-N-C catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) XPS survey spectra of Co-N-C-Phen, Co/N-C-Phen, and Co-N- C-N A, and the corresponding high-resolution XPS spectra of (b) C1s, (c) Co2p, and (d) N1s. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) TEM image, (b) XRD pattern, and (c) High-resolution of XPS spectra of Co-N-C-Phen-H. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) Recyclability of Co-N-C-Phen and Co/N-C-Phen for ethylbenzene oxidation; (b,c) (HR)TEM images, inset chart (b) the particle-size distribution histogram, and (d) XPS spectra of Co-N-C-Phen reused for 10 times. Fig. 6 Table 1 Elemental compositions of the catalysts from XPS. Table 1 Sample Co (%) N (%) O (%) C (%) Total N1 N2 N3 Co-N-C-Phen 0.7 3.5 11.0 34.4 54.6 7.6 88.2 Co/N-C-Phen 1.0 3.9 15.4 25.4 59.2 5.8 89.3 Co-N-C-NA 0.9 3.0 12.6 29.5 57.9 6.9 89.2 Co-N-C-Phen-H 0.5 2.8 14.2 30.0 56.8 6.5 90.2 N1: graphitic quaternary N; N2: pyrrolic N; N3: pyridinic N. Table 2 Catalytic performance of oxidation of ethylbenzene over catalysts. a . Table 2 Entry catalysts conv. (%) sele. (%) TOF d (h−1) AP b AP b 1 Blank 9 76 17 – 2 N-C-Phen 23 74 23 – 3 Co-N-C-NA 20 62 38 1.3 4 NI-Co-N-C-Phen 23 60 40 2.2 5 Co-N-C-PR 30 73 21 2.0 6 Co/N-C-Phen 34 76 21 1.7 7 Co-N-C-Phen 40 75 22 5.3 8 Co-N-C-Buty 37 75 22 2.8 9 Co-N-C-Cap 34 73 22 3.0 10 Co-N-C-His 33 76 22 2.6 11 c Co-N-C-Phen <9 78 18 – 12 Co-N-C-Phen-H 35 80 18 5.0 a Reaction conditions: 10 mL of ethylbenzene, 30 mg of catalyst, O2 (0.8 MPa), 140 °C, 5 h. b Corresponding selectivity (%) to Acetophenone (AP), Phenethyl alcohol (PA). c Reaction conditions: KSCN (0.5 g), the other reaction conditions are as same as ‘a’. d TOF value for the oxidation of ethylbenzene is defined as: the convered [ mol ] Co ( ICP ) [ mol ] * time [ h ] . Table 3 Aerobic oxidation of substituted hydrocarbons using Co-N-C-Phen. a . Table 3 Entry substrate main product T(°C) Conv.(%) Sele.(%) 1 160 11 67 2 120 48 82 3 120 68 73 4 120 92 97 5 160 18 65 6 120 78 56 a Typical conditions: 10 mL of substrate, 30 mg of catalyst, O2 (0.8 MPa), reaction time 5 h. Facile synthesis of ultra-stable Co-N-C catalysts using cobalt porphyrin and peptides as precursors for selective oxidation of ethylbenzene Shanshan Jie Congqiang Yang Yuan Chen Zhigang Liu ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Chemo/Biosensing and Chemometrics, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha 410082, China State Key Laboratory of Chemo/Biosensing and Chemometrics College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Hunan University Changsha 410082 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Intramolecular coordination between cobalt and nitrogen in cobaltporphyrin and axial coordination between metal in porphyrin and nitrogen-enriched peptides are helpful to yield the stable Co-N-C catalysts with excellent catalytic performance. The highly dispersed active sites are desirable to optimize the atom efficiency. In this study, a series of novel cobalt grafted in N-doped carbon (Co-N-C) catalysts for selective oxidation of ethylbenzene are synthesized by heating a solution of cobalt porphyrin and peptides in ionic liquids, which are also characterized by techniques such as FT-IR, XRD, SEM-EDX, HR-TEM, and XPS. The results show that the as-prepared catalysts have an attractive catalytic performance, namely, 40% of ethylbenzene conversion and 75% of selectivity to acetophenone. Especially, the activity and selectivity of the as-prepared catalysts remain almost similar even after the 10th run. Moreover, the modified-complexometry method is verified to improve the dispersion of metal active sites. The remarkable catalytic performance of the as-prepared catalysts is attributed to the highly dispersed active sites and strong interactions between Co and N species in Co-Nx moieties. Keywords Co-N-C Cobalt porphyrin Peptides Ionic liquid Selective oxidation 1 Introduction Over the past decades, metal-based catalysts have inspired numerous interests in selective aerobic oxidation of hydrocarbons due to their high catalytic activity [1–4]. Unfortunately, the metal-based catalysts may suffer from coking and sintering of metal centers, which result in a significant decrease of catalytic performance. Recently, Yu et al. have reported that the doping of nitrogen on carbon nanotubes (CNTs) can enhance the dispersion and stability of platinum (Pt) nanoparticles [5,6]. It reveals that the doping nitrogen may improve the interaction between the metal sites and supports and prevent the aggregation of the metal centers. Due to the high cost of noble metals, such as Pt [7], Pd [8], and Rh [9], transition metals supported on nitrogen-doped carbon (M-N-C) as potential substitutes of noble metal catalysts have attracted an ever-increasing attention [10–12]. Conventionally, the M-N-C catalysts are synthesized via impregnating metal ions onto nitrogen-containing precursors [13–15]. For example, Wang et al. have loaded cobalt nanoparticles on nitrogen doped graphitized carbon shell, which exhibits an excellent catalytic performance for the oxygen reduction reaction and oxygen evolution reaction [16]. However, as for the impregnation method, the metal nanoparticles are usually apt to detach from the support to sintering and growth-up owing to the weak force between metal ions and supports [17]. Recently, the Beller’s group has developed a series of novel M-N-C catalysts via pyrolyzing the metal-phenanthroline complex immobilized on activated carbon [18–20]. These M-N-C catalysts displayed an efficient catalytic performance and relatively high stability in heterogeneous catalytic reaction system. However, the particle sizes of metals are hardly controlled and easy to grow up. Generally, nanoparticles with large sizes not only cause the reduction of atomic efficiency, but also bring about side-reactions [21]. Therefore, developing an efficient, low-cost, and stable and highly dispersed catalyst via a facile method is desirable and still remains a great challenge. In this study, we report a facile method to achieve Co-N-C catalysts, which have well-dispersed active sites and excellent stability for selective oxidation of ethylbenzene under solvent free conditions with oxygen as oxidant. As illustrated in Scheme 1 , the Co-N-C catalysts are synthesized as the following: (i) dissolving amino acids in a solvent of ionic liquid (IL) to form dispersed peptides, (ii) and then connecting the metal by adding another nitrogen and metal precursor molecule, thereby forming an axial coordination structure at the molecular level [22]. Thanks to ILs special properties, it can dissolve metal porphyrin and amino acids at the same time, which may be benefit to forming the well mixing of metal porphyrin and amino acids [23,24]. Moreover, the amino acids can form peptides catalyzed by ILs when heating the homogenous solution of cobaltporphyrin/polypeptide/ionic liquid. Apparently, the metal porphyrin with the metal-N4 structure can efficiently prevent the aggregation of the metal nanoparticles [25,26]. More importantly, the nitrogen-enriched peptides in amino acids can come to form the close interaction between metal in porphyrin and nitrogen in peptides, which can further keep the metal atoms from sintering during the pyrolysis. Due to the dual restriction effect on cobalt, it is expected to yield stable Co-N-C catalysts with well-dispersed active sites for selective oxidation of ethylbenzene. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Benzaldehyde, propanoic acid, pyrrole, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), CoCl2·6H2O, ethanol, ethyl acetate, hydrochloric acid, ethylbenzene, acetophenone, toluene and cyclohexane were commercially available. 1-Butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (BMIM+BF4 −), phenylalanine, histidine, 6-aminocaproic acid, aminobutyric acid and dodecane were purchased from Macklin Reagent Co., Ltd. Hydrindene, 1-indanone, α-tetralone, 1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene, diphenylmethane, benzophenone were purchased from Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts 2.2.1 Preparation of cobalt porphyrin The cobalt porphyrin was synthesized as described in the literature [27]. Typically, 5.56 g of benzaldehyde was loaded in 150 mL of propanoic acid. Then, 4.03 g of freshly distilled pyrrole was added and kept refluxing for 1.0 h. After cooling to room temperature, tetraphenyl porphyrin was collected by filtration and washed with cold water and purified by column chromatography. The obtained sample was marked as TPP. Following that, 1.0 g of TPP was dissolved in 100 mL of DMF and heated at 130 °C for refluxing. Subsequently, 2.0 g of CoCl2·6H2O was gradually added and maintained for another 1.0 h. Finally, 100 mL of deionized water was added, and then, the collected precipitate was filtered, washed by deionized water and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. The obtained compounds were denoted as CoTPP. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Co-N-C catalysts The Co-N-C catalysts were synthesized by a modified-complexometry method. A mixture of 2.0 g of BMIM+BF4 − and 8 mmol of amino acids such as phenylalanine, histidine, 6-aminocaproic acid or aminobutyric acid was heated at 120 °C for 8.0 h, and then 0.2 g of CoTPP was added and kept at 120 °C for 30 min. After cooling to room temperature, the solution was transferred into a quartz boat and heated to 500 °C at a temperature ramp of 5 °C/min under N2 with a gas flow of 100 mL/min and kept at 500 °C for 1.0 h. Based on the different amino acid precursors, the obtained samples were denoted as Co-N-C-Phen, Co-N- C-H is, Co-N-C-Cap and Co-N-C-Buty, respectively. Meanwhile, Co-N-C-Phen-H was obtained from Co-N-C-Phen via acid etching under stirring in 2.0 mol/L of HCl for 4 h [28]. Acting as a control catalyst, NI-Co-N-C-Phen was synthesized via heating a solution of DMF, amino acids, and CoTPP. And, Co-N- C-N A was prepared via the preparation process as Co-N-C-Phen but without amino acid. In addition, a mixture of 2.0 g of BMIM+BF4 − and 8 mmol of phenylalanine was heated and the sample was marked as N-C-Phen, which was without the metal precursor. Co-N-C-PR was obtained through pyrolyzing cobalt porphyrin via the same pyrolysis process as above. Moreover, CoCl2·6H2O instead of CoTPP was selected as the metal precursor to prepare Co-N-C catalyst, which was denoted as Co/N-C-Phen. 2.3 Catalytic performance test The selective oxidation of ethylbenzene over the as-synthesized catalysts was carried out with O2 as the oxidant in a 50 mL of teflon-lined stainless steel reactor. 30 mg of catalyst and 10.0 mL of ethylbenzene were loaded. After the reactor was sealed, O2 pressure was increased to 0.8 MPa, and then the reactor was heated to 140 °C and kept for 5 h. The products were analyzed by Echrom A90 with an internal standard method, in which the bromobenzene and 1,4-dichlorobenzene were used as references. In addition, to investigate the stability of the catalysts, Co-N-C-Phen was centrifuged and washed with alcohol for 3 times after the reaction, and then dried at 80 °C overnight before reuse. Besides, poisoning experiment was conducted, in which 0.5 g of KSCN selected as the poison was added into the reactants [28]. 2.4 Leaching test The leaching test was performed to identify that no substantial leaching of the cobalt species occurred in the solution. Typically, a 50 mL of teflon-lined stainless-steel reactor was filled with a mixture of ethylbenzene (10 mL) and catalyst (30 mg) under 0.8 MPa O2 pressure and heated at 140 °C for 8 h. Then, the catalyst was isolated from the hot reaction mixture by centrifugation. Subsequently, the ICP-AES analysis of the filtrate was performed to ensure whether any leaching of cobalt species took place. 2.5 Characterization Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra were obtained on a Vertex 70 (Bruker) Fourier transform infrared spectrometer. Mass spectrometry (MS) spectrum was conducted using a MOLDI-TOF REFLEX-III (Bruker) with wavelength of 337 nm. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) studies were performed on a Tecnai F20 operated at an accelerating voltage of 120 kV. Scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDX) images were recorded on FEI Quanta 200 with image corrector operating at 300 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted using a VG ESCA 2000 with an Mg Kα source and the C1s peak at 284.6 eV was used as the reference to correct the binding energies (BEs). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired on a D8-Advanced diffractometer system from Bruker with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). In addition, Co contents of the samples were analyzed with a simultaneous ICP-AES allied analytical system (Optima5300DV, Perkin Elemer). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization In this study, IL, BMIM+BF4 −, has employed as the solvent for amino acids and CoTPP. Moreover, it can act as the catalyst for amino acids to peptides. As illustrated in Fig. 1 a, when amino acids are loaded in ILs and heated at 120 °C for 1 h, it can be found that the color of the obtained solution becomes yellow from white, and then a solid sample can be obtained when deionized water is added. In Fig. 1b, the FT-IR is presented and used to analyze the functional groups. Compared to the phenylalanine, the peaks at 1691 cm−1, 1603 cm−1, and 1519 cm−1 in the obtained solid sample are attributed to the characteristic absorption bands of amide bond, which are corresponding to the CO stretching vibration, NH- bending vibration, and C–N stretching vibration, respectively [29]. In addition, the Mass spectrometry (MS) of the obtained solid sample reveals the existence of peptides (seen in Fig. S1). The results agree well with Ryu’s report that ILs can provide a coupling-reagent-free approach to synthesize dipeptides and tripeptides [30]. In Fig. 1c, the TEM image clearly shows that the metal nanoparticles, as for the as-synthesized Co-N-C-Phen, are highly dispersed on the carbon support with a narrow size distribution in the range of 3–6 nm. Furthermore, in Fig. 1d, the spacings of cobalt nanoparticles are 0.29 nm and 0.21 nm, which can be attributed to the (220) plane of Co3O4 and the (111) plane of Co°, respectively. Energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDX) element mapping has employed to investigate the distribution of C, N, O, and Co in Co-N-C-Phen, which indicates a uniform dispersion of the four elements in the hybrids (Fig. 1e, Fig. S2). However, as shown in Fig. 2 a–c, the agglomeration of metallic cobalt species can be observed in NI-Co-N-C-Phen, Co-N- C-N A and Co-N-C-PR. Obviously, Co-N-C-Phen synthesized via the given method may have a well-dispersed metal nanoparticles. Generally, in the homogeneous peptides/ILs solution, electron-donating groups (N or CO) existing in peptide chains can offer additional possibilities to give axial coordination with the adjacent Co atom in CoTPP, which can strengthen the interaction between metal and support, and then effectively lower the aggregation of metal nanoparticles [31,32]. In addition, the TEM images of Co-N-C-Cap, Co-N-C-Buty, and Co-N- C-H is synthesized using different amino acids as precursors are presented in Fig. 2d–f. Interestingly, the metal nanoparticles in these catalysts are also uniformly distributed, indicating the effectiveness of this method to all kinds of amino acids. As shown in Fig. 3 , the as-prepared catalysts are characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD). The peaks at 2θ of 44.2°, 75.8°, and 51.3° are observed in Co-N-C-PR, corresponding to Co° and Co2O3, respectively. However, there are no peaks of metal nanoparticles to detect in Co-N-C-phen, indicating that the metal nanoparticles have not been sintered during pyrolysis and are well-dispersed, which is in good agreement with the results in TEM. In addition, as displayed in Fig. S3, the peaks of cobalt cannot be detected in Co-N-C-Cap, Co-N-C-Buty, and Co-N- C-H is, too. XPS measurement has been performed to investigate the surface compositions of Co-N-C-Phen, Co/N-C-Phen (CoCl2·6H2O as metal precursor) and Co-N- C-N A. As illustrated in Fig. 4 a, the peaks of C, N, O, and Co have been observed in the survey spectra of all the samples. The high-resolution C1s spectra of Co-N-C-Phen, Co/N-C-Phen and Co-N- C-N A have four peaks, and defined as CC (284.6 eV), C–N (285.3 eV), C–O (286.0 eV) and CO (287.1 eV), respectively (Fig. 4b) [33]. Moreover, as summarized in Table 1 , the content of C–N (22%) in Co-N-C-Phen is higher than that of Co/N-C-Phen (19%) and Co-N- C-N A (11%), which may play the key role in the catalytic performance of Co-N-C catalysts [34]. In respect of the high resolution XPS spectra of Co2p, as exhibited in Fig. 4c, the peak at around 778.5 eV is consistent with the binding energy (BE) of Co°, and the presence at 780.0 eV and 796.1 eV are in line with the BE of oxidic Co. Additionally, the BE of 781.2 eV is ascribed to Co2+ with the formation of Co-Nx, and the peak at 783.5 eV signifies the strong interaction between cobalt nanoparticles and doping nitrogen [35–37]. It is noteworthy that the BE of Co-Nx in Co-N-C-Phen is lower than that of the Co/N-C-Phen and Co-N- C-N A, which is attributed to the π-electron delocalization via both the intramolecular coordination and axial coordination [38]. Obviously, the intramolecular coordination between metal and nitrogen precursors of CoTPP, and the axial coordination between CoTPP and peptides are helpful to generate the powerful Co-N bond. The high-resolution N1s spectra of Co-N-C-Phen, Co/N-C-Phen, and Co-N- C-N A show that the nitrogen has three states, namely, graphitic quaternary N (N1, 401–403 eV), pyrrolic N (N2, 400 ± 0.3 eV) and pyridinic N (N3, 397–399 eV), as listed in Fig. 4d. For Co-N-C-Phen catalyst, the N2, N3 occupy the major nitrogen content. Moreover, compared with Co/N-C-Phen (25.4%) and Co-N- C-N A (29.5%), the content of N2 bonding to cobalt has remarkable increased in Co-N-C-Phen (34.4%) (Table 1), which suggests the introduction of CoTPP and amino acids can obtain higher density of Co-Nx. The N2, N3 may have the potential to act as Lewis base and then enhance the immobilization of nanoparticles. In addition, previous reports show that the metal-containing nanoparticles are mostly encapsulated by carbon nanoshells through pyrolysis metal-N4 macrocyclic molecules or synthetic materials containing metal/nitrogen/carbon elements, which can effectively improve the catalytic activity and stability [39,40]. As a result, the Co-N-C-x catalysts with highly dispersed metal nanoparticle and stable Co-Nx can be synthesized through pyrolyzing cobaltporphyrin/polypeptide/ionic liquid, which are supposed to be beneficial for catalytic activity and stability. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Activity of catalysts Extensive experiments were used to investigate the catalytic performance of Co-N-C catalysts, such as the C–H selective oxidation, catalytic hydrogenation coupling, electrocatalysis [31,32,41]. Here, the selective oxidation of ethylbenzene to acetophenone with molecular oxygen as oxidant under solvent-free conditions is employed to evaluate the catalytic performance of Co-N-C catalysts. As shown in Table 2 , a very low ethylbenzene conversion of 9% (entry 1) can be obtained in autocatalysis system. In respect of N-C-Phen, a slightly improved catalytic activity with 23% of ethylbenzene conversion has observed (entry 2). With Co-N- C-N A and NI-Co-N-C-Phen as the catalysts, the conversion of ethylbenzene is 20% and 23%, respectively (entries 3,4). Meanwhile, the Co-N-C-PR (30%) catalyst shows moderate activity with similar ethylbenzene conversion of Co/N-C-Phen (34%) (entries 5,6). As expected, the as-synthesized Co-N-C-Phen obtained the highest catalytic activity with 40% of ethylbenzene conversion and 75% of acetophenone selectivity (entry 7). The results suggest that the amino acids, ILs, and CoTPP are indispensable in the preparation of high efficient Co-N-C catalysts. At the same time, the catalytic performance of various Co-N-C-x catalysts has explored to identify the unique structures of the as-prepared Co-N-C catalysts. As shown in Table 2 (entries 8–10), all the prepared Co-N-C-x catalysts exhibit relatively high conversions, which illustrates the effectiveness of this method. In order to further confirm the involvement of Co in the catalysis, a poison of KSCN has been added in Co-N-C-Phen catalytic system. As shown in entry 11 (Table 2), the acetophenone is hardly detected in the presence of KSCN, suggesting the indispensable of cobalt in the catalysis. In addition, to expose the real active sites, the influence of Co3O4 has been checked. In the case of the HCl washed Co-N-C-Phen-H catalyst, the conversion of ethylbenzene decreases to 35% (entry 12). Obviously, the Co3O4 has an influence on the catalytic activity, yet it is not the major contributor. From the TOF values calculated on the basis of cobalt loading for the oxidation of ethylbenzene, it is showed that the Co-N-C-Phen catalyst possesses higher value, indicating a superior catalytic performance. Moreover, Co-N-C-Phen-H and Co-N-C-Phen have the similar TOF values, which are greater than the values of other control samples. Some characterizations are performed to investigate the structure and composition of Co-N-C-Phen-H. The result of TEM indicates the nanoparticles highly dispersed on the support (Fig. 5 a). And, there are barely metal peaks have been observed in the XRD pattern (Fig. 5b). Compared with the Co-N-C-Phen, XPS spectra of the Co-N-C-Phen-H display a little decline of the cobalt and nitrogen content, which is consistent with the experiment result (Fig. 5c, Table 1). Zhang et al. reported that Co bonded with N in Co-N-C catalysts is primary active site, whereas those particles of Co or CoOx are secondary important role in aerobic oxidative [32]. Herein, according to the report and the results of characterization and experiment, the superior catalytic performance of Co-N-C-Phen is attributed to the promotion effect of Co-Nx moieties. Apparently, the method used in this work can effectively enhance catalytic performance of the catalysts by improving the dispersion of metal nanoparticles and enhancing the interaction between metal and doping nitrogen. Furthermore, the representative Co-N-C-Phen also has a good catalytic performance in aerobic oxidation of diverse substrates and the results are listed in Table 3 . 3.2.2 Reusability of catalysts The reusability of Co-N-C-Phen has been measured for the selective oxidation of ethylbenzene at 140 °C and 0.8 MPa. As shown in Fig. 6 a, Co-N-C-Phen shows remarkable reusability, retaining 90% of its initial activity in the tenth run. The outstanding recyclability should be ascribed to the intrinsic structure characteristics of CoTPP that containing powerful Co-N species in the framework and the powerful coordination between CoTPP and peptides. To confirm the indispensable of coordination in CoTPP, the reusability of Co/N-C-Phen catalyst has been conducted. Although the relatively high conversion can be obtained in ethylbenzene oxidation, in terms of the stability of the catalyst, Co/N-C-Phen shows a poor stability. These results indicate that the stable and un-negligible Co-N bond of CoTPP can achieve an extra stability. Meanwhile, the XPS reveals that the N2 dominates the major factors for the high reusability (Table 1). Several characterization techniques are used to examine the structure and composition of the reused Co-N-C-Phen. As shown in Fig. 6b and c, the TEM images illustrate that the Co nanoparticles are distributed uniformly without aggregation after the recycle. According to the XPS results, as shown Fig. 6d and Table S1, the ratio of Co-Nx to Co3O4 in the reused Co-N-C-Phen catalyst (ca. 0.64) is similar to that in the fresh one (ca. 0.71), which suggest that the structure and composition of Co-N-C-Phen catalyst can be well maintained after reuse. Moreover, the leaching test has performed to identify that no substantial leaching of the cobalt species occurred in the solution of including Co-N-C-Phen. In the case, the Co-N-C-Phen catalyst has isolated via centrifugation and the filtrate has performed ICP-AES analysis. The quantitative analysis from ICP-AES indicates the content of Co in filtrate is below the detection limit. Consequently, based on the above analyses, the remarkable catalytic activity and stability of the Co-N-C-Phen catalyst can be attributed to the highly dispersed active sites and powerful interactions between Co and N. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have synthesized Co-N-C-x catalysts through a modified-complexometry method. The prepared catalysts have small particle sizes and well-dispersed active sites. In particularly, Co-N-C-Phen exhibits an attractive catalytic performance for selective oxidation of various substrates with molecular oxygen as oxidant under solvent-free conditions. Furthermore, Co-N-C-Phen catalyst shows a remarkable stability that can be reused for ten times without apparently deactivation. Experiment and characterization results indicate that the introduction of pyrrolic N existing in CoTPP can improve the catalytic activity and stability due to the stable Co-N bond. Moreover, the axial coordination between cobalt in cobaltporphyrin and nitrogen in peptides can be beneficial to generating and dispersing the active sites. It is expected that the synthesis method reported here may create new opportunities for preparing M-N-C catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The highly dispersed active sites are desirable to optimize the atom efficiency. In this study, a series of novel cobalt grafted in N-doped carbon (Co-N-C) catalysts for selective oxidation of ethylbenzene are synthesized by heating a solution of cobalt porphyrin and peptides in ionic liquids, which are also characterized by techniques such as FT-IR, XRD, SEM-EDX, HR-TEM, and XPS. The results show that the as-prepared catalysts have an attractive catalytic performance, namely, 40% of ethylbenzene conversion and 75% of selectivity to acetophenone. Especially, the activity and selectivity of the as-prepared catalysts remain almost similar even after the 10th run. Moreover, the modified-complexometry method is verified to improve the dispersion of metal active sites. The remarkable catalytic performance of the as-prepared catalysts is attributed to the highly dispersed active sites and strong interactions between Co and N species in Co-Nx moieties.
coredata.dc:title: Facile synthesis of ultra-stable Co-N-C catalysts using cobalt porphyrin and peptides as precursors for selective oxidation of ethylbenzene
